Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Complexity of Global Change - Interactive Effects of Warming, Water Availability, CO2 and N on Grassland Ecosystem Function
Award.AbstractNarration:
Changes in temperature, precipitation, atmospheric CO2 concentration, and nitrogen deposition will likely continue to occur throughout the 21st century and will have significant impacts on forests, grasslands, and other vegetation across the planet. However, the effects of each of these factors alone may depend on changes in the other factors, and such interactions are poorly understood. Given this scientific gap, the objective of the proposed study is to increase understanding of the interactive effects of warming, precipitation, CO2, and nitrogen on long-term ecosystem responses. To meet this objective, experimental manipulations will be imposed in a unique open-air grassland experiment in Minnesota, to create all combinations of ambient and elevated temperature (ambient and +2Â°C), current and reduced growing season precipitation (ambient rainfall and 55% of ambient rainfall), ambient and elevated CO2 (current levels and those likely to occur late in the century), and ambient and enriched nitrogen supply (achieved with two levels of soil nitrogen supply). The study will determine the interactive effects of these four global change factors on performance of plants and soil organisms, and hence on plant production, soil fertility, and carbon acquisition and storage. Results of this project will also help in the development of models that predict how changes in vegetation will influence the global climate system through modifying the rise in atmospheric carbon dioxide levels and thus the rate of climate warming.

This project will educate a diverse group of undergraduates, including students from under-represented groups, and build ties to scientists from around the U.S. and the world. Results will be incorporated into outreach activities aimed at K-12 educators and aimed at training teachers in global change and sustainability curricula. Researchers will educate students and the public through classes, interviews with the press, participation in public forums, and advising government officials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Changes in temperature, precipitation, atmospheric carbon dioxide (CO2) concentration, and nitrogen (N) deposition will likely occur throughout the 21st century and have significant impacts on forests, grasslands, and other vegetation across the planet. However, the effects of each of these factors may depend on changes in the other factors, and such interactions are poorly understood at present. Given this scientific gap, the objective of this study was to increase understanding of the interactive effects of warming, precipitation, CO2, and nitrogen on long-term ecosystem response to potentially serve both theoretical and societal needs. These efforts built on an existing open-air grassland experiment in Minnesota where experimental manipulations create all combinations of ambient and elevated temperature (ambient and +2°C), current and reduced growing season precipitation (ambient rainfall and 55% of ambient rainfall), ambient and elevated CO2 (current levels and those likely to occur late in the 21st century), and ambient and enriched nitrogen supply (achieved with two levels of soil nitrogen supply).

The outcomes of this collaborative portion of the larger project described above, have revealed how plant physiological responses to elevated CO2 are affected by changes in soil N and water supply or by warmer temperatures. The incorporation of carbon into organic molecules by photosynthesis and the opening and closing of stomata (pores on plant surfaces) are plant physiological processes that critically regulate the uptake of carbon and loss of water by vegetation. Basic biochemistry predicts that with more CO2 in the atmosphere, plants will take up more CO2 in photosynthesis and ultimately grow bigger. However, increases in photosynthetic CO2 uptake were only modest, indicating that plants acclimated (changed physiologically) to growth at elevated CO2. This photosynthetic response to elevated CO2 was not affected by increased N supply or warmer conditions. Growth under elevated CO2 did reduce plant water loss, however, which ultimately led to an increased efficiency of water use during photosynthesis. This water-saving effect will likely have indirect or cascading effects on ecosystem functioning as a whole. Finally, the effects of these global change factors on symbiotic nitrogen fixation by plant species (legumes) that form associations with atmospheric N fixing bacteria were also investigated to determine whether legumes might contribute more N to ecosystems in the future.

These results may improve the accuracy of models that depend on leaf and plant-level scale inputs to predict how global change factors of atmospheric CO2, reduced precipitation, and warming will influence vegetation. Carbon cycle models that assume, and thereby simulate, strong stimulation of photosynthetic uptake of CO2 for Earth’s terrestrial ecosystems should be considered carefully. 

This project has contributed to the education of a diverse group of undergraduates, including under-represented groups. Students participated in summer internships that included independent research opportunities as part of the summer research assistant program. The project described herein has also contributed data that is used in an introductory plant biology class (UWEC) and is to be developed ultimately for wider use. All undergraduate students who have conducted research related to this grant have presented their results at the UW-Eau Claire Celebration of Research and Creative Activity that occurs each spring. This is a well-attended event by not only our university community but the local community and state government representatives.
